title: Getting to Cape Cod
content:
Cape Cod, a beautiful peninsula in Massachusetts, is accessible by various means of transportation. Here are the most common ways to reach Cape Cod:

  1. By Car:
    Driving is the most flexible option. From Boston, take I-93 South and then merge onto Route 3 South. Follow the signs for Cape Cod via the Sagamore Bridge or the Bourne Bridge. The drive takes approximately 1.5 to 2 hours, depending on your destination on the Cape.
  2. By Bus:
    Several bus companies, such as Plymouth & Brockton Street Railway Company and Peter Pan Bus Lines, offer services from Boston to various towns on Cape Cod. Buses depart from South Station and Logan Airport, taking around 2 to 3 hours to reach the Cape.
  3. By Plane:
    Cape Cod has a small airport, Barnstable Municipal Airport (HYA), which is served by regional airlines like Cape Air and JetBlue. You can fly directly from Boston's Logan Airport, which takes about 30 minutes. Alternatively, you can fly to Boston or Providence, Rhode Island, and then rent a car or take a bus to reach Cape Cod.
  4. By Train:
    The Cape Flyer is a seasonal train service that runs from Boston's South Station to Hyannis on Cape Cod. The train operates on weekends and holidays during the summer months, typically from Memorial Day through Labor Day. The journey takes approximately 2.5 hours.
  5. By Ferry:
    Ferries run from Boston to Provincetown, located at the tip of Cape Cod. The fast ferry, operated by Bay State Cruise Company, takes around 90 minutes, while the traditional ferry takes about 3 hours. Ferries usually operate from May through October.

Regardless of your chosen mode of transportation, it's advisable to plan ahead and make reservations, especially during the peak summer season, to ensure a smooth and enjoyable journey to Cape Cod.

title: Accommodation Guides
content:
Cape Cod offers a wide range of accommodation options to suit every traveler's preferences and budget. Whether you're looking for a luxurious hotel, a cozy bed and breakfast, or a vacation rental property, you'll find plenty of choices across the Cape. Here are some insights to help you decide where to stay:

Hotels:

Cape Cod has a variety of hotels, from high-end resorts to budget-friendly options. Many hotels are located in popular towns like Hyannis, Falmouth, and Provincetown. Consider factors such as location, amenities, and seasonality when booking a hotel.

Bed and Breakfasts (B&Bs):

For a more intimate and charming experience, consider staying at a bed and breakfast. B&Bs are often housed in historic buildings and offer personalized service, homemade breakfasts, and a unique atmosphere. You can find B&Bs throughout Cape Cod, particularly in scenic areas like Chatham and Yarmouth.

Vacation Rentals:

Vacation rentals, including houses, cottages, and apartments, are a popular choice for families and groups. They offer more space, privacy, and flexibility compared to hotels. Rental properties are available in various sizes and styles, from beachfront homes to quaint cottages. Popular websites like Airbnb and VRBO have a wide selection of vacation rentals across Cape Cod.

Budget Considerations:

Accommodation prices in Cape Cod vary depending on factors such as location, season, and amenities. Peak season (June to August) tends to have higher prices, while shoulder seasons (April to May and September to October) offer more affordable rates. Consider booking in advance to secure better deals and availability.

Regardless of your chosen accommodation type, it's essential to research and compare options to find the best fit for your needs and budget. Read reviews, check amenities, and consider factors like proximity to attractions and beaches to ensure a memorable stay in Cape Cod.

content.tagline: Discover the vibrant art scene, stunning beaches, and inclusive culture of Provincetown.
content.description: Provincetown, located at the tip of Cape Cod, is known for its thriving art community, beautiful beaches, and LGBTQ+ friendly atmosphere. Explore the colorful Commercial Street, visit art galleries, and enjoy the lively nightlife. Don't miss the Pilgrim Monument and the Cape Cod National Seashore.

content.tagline: Experience the charm and elegance of Chatham, a picturesque coastal town.
content.description: Chatham is a quintessential New England town with a charming Main Street, historic lighthouse, and beautiful beaches. Visit the Chatham Lighthouse, stroll through the boutiques and art galleries, and savor fresh seafood at local restaurants. Take a scenic drive along Shore Road and enjoy the stunning ocean views.

content.tagline: Explore the hub of Cape Cod: Hyannis, where entertainment and history meet.
content.description: Hyannis, the largest town in Cape Cod, offers a perfect blend of entertainment, shopping, and history. Visit the John F. Kennedy Hyannis Museum, enjoy live music at the Cape Cod Melody Tent, and shop at the Main Street boutiques. Take a harbor cruise or ferry to nearby Nantucket or Martha's Vineyard.

content.tagline: Unwind in the picturesque town of Falmouth, known for its stunning beaches and outdoor activities.
content.description: Falmouth is a charming coastal town with beautiful beaches, scenic bike trails, and a vibrant downtown. Visit Old Silver Beach, cycle along the Shining Sea Bikeway, and explore the historic Highfield Hall & Gardens. Enjoy fresh seafood at local restaurants and take a stroll through the charming Queen's Buyway shops.

content.tagline: Immerse yourself in the natural beauty and artistic spirit of Wellfleet.
content.description: Wellfleet is a haven for nature lovers and art enthusiasts. Explore the pristine beaches of the Cape Cod National Seashore, visit the Wellfleet Bay Wildlife Sanctuary, and gallery-hop along the vibrant Main Street. Don't miss the famous Wellfleet Oyster Festival in the fall.

content.tagline: Step back in time and relax in the quaint town of Brewster.
content.description: Brewster, known as the "Sea Captain's Town," offers a glimpse into Cape Cod's rich maritime history. Visit the Brewster Historical Society Museum, explore the antique shops along Route 6A, and enjoy the serene beauty of Breakwater Beach. Play a round of golf at the renowned Cape Cod National Golf Club.

content.tagline: Family-friendly fun and endless adventures await in Yarmouth.
content.description: Yarmouth is a perfect destination for families, offering a variety of activities and attractions. Visit the Whydah Pirate Museum, spend a day at the Inflatable Park, and enjoy mini-golf at Pirates Cove. Relax on the sandy beaches of Seagull Beach and explore the trails of the Bass Hole Boardwalk.

title: Staying Safe
content:
Tips for Staying Safe in Cape Cod

Cape Cod is generally a safe place to visit, but it's always wise to take precautions to ensure a safe and enjoyable trip. Here are some tips to keep in mind:

  • Be aware of your surroundings and avoid walking alone in unfamiliar areas at night.
  • Lock your vehicle and keep valuables out of sight.
  • Protect yourself from the sun by wearing sunscreen, hats, and sunglasses.
  • Be cautious when swimming in the ocean, as rip currents can be strong. Always obey posted beach safety signs.
  • Watch out for ticks, especially when hiking in wooded areas. Wear insect repellent and check yourself for ticks after outdoor activities.

Healthcare Facilities

In case of a medical emergency, Cape Cod has several healthcare facilities available:

  • Cape Cod Hospital in Hyannis
  • Falmouth Hospital in Falmouth
  • Outer Cape Health Services in Provincetown, Wellfleet, and Harwich

For non-emergency medical needs, there are numerous urgent care centers and walk-in clinics throughout Cape Cod.

Sun and Tick Safety

Cape Cod's beautiful beaches and outdoor activities make it important to prioritize sun and tick safety:

  • Apply sunscreen with an SPF of at least 30 and reapply every 2 hours.
  • Wear protective clothing, such as long-sleeved shirts and pants, when hiking or exploring wooded areas.
  • Perform thorough tick checks after spending time outdoors, especially in grassy or wooded areas.
  • If you find a tick attached to your skin, remove it carefully with tweezers and monitor the area for any signs of infection or rash.

By following these safety tips and being aware of the available resources, you can ensure a safe and enjoyable visit to Cape Cod.

title: Historical Attractions
content:
Discover the Rich History of Cape Cod

Cape Cod has a fascinating history dating back to the early days of American settlement. Here are some notable historical attractions to visit:

  • Pilgrim Monument and Provincetown Museum
    Address: 1 High Pole Hill Rd, Provincetown, MA 02657
    Website: https://www.pilgrim-monument.org/
  • Cape Cod National Seashore
    Address: 99 Marconi Site Road, Wellfleet, MA 02667
    Website: https://www.nps.gov/caco/index.htm
  • Chatham Lighthouse
    Address: 37 Main St, Chatham, MA 02633
    Website: https://www.us-lighthouses.com/chatham-lighthouse
  • Sandwich Glass Museum
    Address: 129 Main St, Sandwich, MA 02563
    Website: https://sandwichglassmuseum.org/
  • John F. Kennedy Hyannis Museum
    Address: 397 Main St, Hyannis, MA 02601
    Website: https://www.jfkhyannismuseum.org/
  • Whydah Pirate Museum
    Address: 674 MA-28, West Yarmouth, MA 02673
    Website: https://www.discoverpirates.com/

These are just a few of the many historical attractions Cape Cod has to offer. Each site provides a unique glimpse into the region's past and offers visitors an enriching educational experience.

title: Seasonal Events & Festivals
content:
Experience the Magic of Summer on Cape Cod

Summer on Cape Cod is filled with a vibrant array of events and festivals that celebrate the region's culture, cuisine, and natural beauty. Here are some noteworthy summer events:

  • Provincetown International Film Festival
    Date: June
    Website: https://provincetownfilm.org/festival/
  • Cape Cod Hydrangea Festival
    Date: July
    Website: https://capecodchamber.org/hydrangea-fest/
  • Barnstable County Fair
    Date: July
    Website: https://capecodfairgrounds.com/events/barnstable-county-fair/
  • Yarmouth Summer Celebration
    Date: July
    Website: https://yarmouthsummercelebration.com/
  • Cape Cod Jazz Festival
    Date: August
    Website: https://www.artsfoundation.org/jazz-festival
  • Falmouth Road Race
    Date: August
    Website: https://falmouthroadrace.com/
  • Cape Cod Brew Fest
    Date: September
    Website: https://www.capecodbrewfest.com/

These events showcase the best of Cape Cod's arts, culture, and outdoor activities. Be sure to check the official websites for specific dates, locations, and ticket information when planning your summer visit.

title: What to do on a Rainy Day
content:
Explore Indoor Activities on Cape Cod

Don't let a rainy day dampen your spirits! Cape Cod offers plenty of indoor activities to keep you entertained. Here are some ideas:

  • Visit Museums
    - Cape Cod Museum of Art (https://ccmoa.org/)
    - John F. Kennedy Hyannis Museum (https://www.jfkhyannismuseum.org/)
    - Sandwich Glass Museum (https://sandwichglassmuseum.org/)
  • Explore Local Shops
    - Main Street, Hyannis
    - Commercial Street, Provincetown
    - Mashpee Commons (https://mashpeecommons.com/)
  • Enjoy Indoor Entertainment
    - Cape Cod Mall, Hyannis (https://www.simon.com/mall/cape-cod-mall)
    - Ryan Family Amusements, Yarmouth (https://ryanfamily.com/)
    - Wackenhammer's Clockwork Arcade, Hyannis (https://www.wackenhammers.com/)
  • Indulge in Local Cuisine
    - Seafood Restaurants
    - Cozy Cafes
    - Craft Breweries

A rainy day on Cape Cod is a perfect opportunity to explore the region's indoor attractions, shop for unique souvenirs, and savor the local cuisine. Embrace the slower pace and make the most of your time indoors!

title: Cape Cod Baseball League
content:
Experience the Excitement of the Cape Cod Baseball League

The Cape Cod Baseball League (CCBL) is a prestigious collegiate summer baseball league that attracts top talent from across the country. Here's what you need to know:

  • About the League
    The CCBL is a 10-team league featuring some of the nation's best college baseball players. The league has a long history dating back to 1885 and has produced numerous Major League Baseball stars.
  • Teams and Locations
    - Bourne Braves (https://bournebraves.org/)
    - Brewster Whitecaps (https://whitecaps-baseball.com/)
    - Chatham Anglers (https://chathamanglers.com/)
    - Cotuit Kettleers (https://kettleers.org/)
    - Falmouth Commodores (https://falmouthcommodores.com/)
    - Harwich Mariners (https://harwichmariners.org/)
    - Hyannis Harbor Hawks (https://harborhawks.org/)
    - Orleans Firebirds (https://orleansfirebirds.com/)
    - Wareham Gatemen (https://gatemen.org/)
    - Yarmouth-Dennis Red Sox (https://ydredsox.com/)
  • Schedule and Tickets
    The CCBL season runs from mid-June to early August, with games played daily. Tickets are affordable and can be purchased at the gate or through team websites.
  • Experience
    Attending a CCBL game is a quintessential Cape Cod summer experience. Enjoy the relaxed atmosphere, cheer on the talented players, and soak in the beautiful surroundings of the Cape's historic ballparks.

Don't miss the chance to witness future MLB stars in action! Check the league schedule and catch a game or two during your Cape Cod visit.

title: Dining & Food
content:
Savor the Flavors of Cape Cod

Cape Cod is renowned for its delicious seafood and diverse culinary scene. Here are some dining and food experiences not to miss:

  • Seafood Shacks
    - The Lobster Pot, Provincetown (https://www.ptownlobsterpot.com/)
    - The Raw Bar, Mashpee (https://therawbar.com/)
    - Sesuit Harbor Cafe, Dennis (https://sesuit-harbor-cafe.com/)
  • Fine Dining
    - The Ocean House Restaurant, Dennis (https://oceanhouserestaurant.com/)
    - Twenty-Eight Atlantic, Harwich (https://wequassett.com/dining/)
    - The Naked Oyster, Hyannis (https://nakedoyster.com/)
  • Local Specialties
    - Lobster Rolls
    - Fried Clams
    - Oysters
    - New England Clam Chowder
    - Cape Cod Potato Chips (https://www.capecodchips.com/)
  • Farmers Markets and Food Festivals
    - Barnstable Village Farmers Market (https://www.barnstablevillagefarmersmarket.org/)
    - Provincetown Farmers Market (https://www.provincetownfarmersmarket.com/)
    - Wellfleet OysterFest (https://www.wellfleetspat.org/oysterfest)

Whether you're looking for casual seafood shacks, fine dining experiences, or local specialties, Cape Cod has something to satisfy every palate. Don't forget to visit the farmers markets and food festivals for a taste of the Cape's freshest produce and culinary delights!

title: Sharks & Jellyfish
content:
Understanding Sharks and Jellyfish on Cape Cod

While sharks and jellyfish are present in Cape Cod waters, it's important to keep their presence in perspective and take appropriate precautions. Here's what you need to know:

  • Sharks
    - Cape Cod is home to several shark species, including white sharks (great white sharks).
    - Shark sightings and encounters are relatively rare, but it's essential to stay informed and follow beach safety guidelines.
    - Pay attention to warning signs, flags, and lifeguard instructions at the beach.
    - Avoid swimming in areas known for shark activity, especially near seals, which are a primary food source for white sharks.
  • Jellyfish
    - Jellyfish, particularly lion's mane jellyfish, can be found in Cape Cod waters during the summer months.
    - While lion's mane jellyfish stings can be painful, they are rarely life-threatening.
    - If stung by a jellyfish, rinse the affected area with seawater (not fresh water) and apply vinegar or a cold pack to relieve pain and inflammation.
    - Seek medical attention if you experience severe pain, allergic reactions, or difficulty breathing.
  • General Precautions
    - Swim in designated areas with lifeguards present.
    - Stay informed about current beach conditions and any warnings issued by local authorities.
    - Avoid swimming at dawn, dusk, or night when shark activity may be higher.
    - If you spot a shark or jellyfish, calmly exit the water and alert a lifeguard or beach official.

By staying informed, following beach safety guidelines, and exercising caution, you can safely enjoy Cape Cod's beautiful beaches while minimizing the risk of shark or jellyfish encounters.

For more information and updates, visit the Atlantic White Shark Conservancy and the Massachusetts Division of Marine Fisheries websites.

title: Getting Out (Leaving the Cape)
content:
Leaving Cape Cod: Transportation Options and Tips

When it's time to say goodbye to Cape Cod, you have several transportation options to choose from. Here's a guide to help you plan your departure:

  • By Car
    - If you're driving, plan your route and check traffic conditions before leaving, especially during peak travel times.
    - Be prepared for potential delays at the Sagamore Bridge and Bourne Bridge, which connect the Cape to the mainland.
    - Consider taking Route 6 (Mid-Cape Highway) or Route 28 (Falmouth Highway) to exit the Cape, depending on your destination.
  • By Bus
    - Bus companies such as Plymouth & Brockton Street Railway Company and Peter Pan Bus Lines offer service from various Cape Cod towns to destinations like Boston, Providence, and New York City.
    - Check bus schedules and book your tickets in advance to ensure a smooth departure.
  • By Ferry
    - If you're heading to Nantucket or Martha's Vineyard, you can take a ferry from Hyannis, Harwich Port, or Woods Hole.
    - Ferry schedules vary by season, so check the timetables and make reservations ahead of time.
  • By Plane
    - If you're flying out of Cape Cod, Barnstable Municipal Airport (HYA) in Hyannis offers flights to destinations like Boston, New York City, and Nantucket.
    - For international flights or a wider selection of destinations, you may need to travel to Boston Logan International Airport (BOS) or T.F. Green Airport (PVD) in Providence, Rhode Island.

Regardless of your transportation choice, be sure to plan ahead, allow extra time for potential delays, and check the latest schedules and updates before your departure.

For more information on transportation options and schedules, visit the Cape Cod Chamber of Commerce website.

title: Books, Music & Film
content:
Discover Cape Cod through Books, Music, and Film

Immerse yourself in the rich cultural heritage of Cape Cod through its literature, music, and film. Here are some recommendations to enhance your experience:

  • Books
    - "The Outermost House" by Henry Beston
    - "Cape Cod" by Henry David Thoreau
    - "The Old Man and the Sea" by Ernest Hemingway
    - "Remaining on the Vine" by Jane Willan
    - "Cape Cod Noir" by David L. Ulin (Editor)
  • Music
    - Cape Cod Chamber Music Festival (https://capecodchambermusic.org/)
    - Payomet Performing Arts Center (https://payomet.org/)
    - Cape Cod Jazz Festival (https://www.artsfoundation.org/jazz-festival)
    - Local music venues and bars featuring live performances
  • Film
    - "Summer Catch" (2001)
    - "The Golden Boys" (2008)
    - "The Lightkeepers" (2009)
    - "The Finest Hours" (2016)
    - Woods Hole Film Festival (https://www.woodsholefilmfestival.org/)
    - Provincetown International Film Festival (https://provincetownfilm.org/festival/)

These books, music events, and films offer a glimpse into the unique culture, history, and beauty of Cape Cod. Explore local bookstores, attend live music performances, and keep an eye out for film festivals and screenings during your visit.

For more information on cultural events and attractions, visit the Cape Cod Chamber of Commerce website.
